tspan.tspan: Each thread has its own parts
1. A small amount of memory. It can be viewed as the current thread execution line
number in the class file. By changing the value of PC register, the next command is
2. Many threads execution at once is achieved by switching the current thread and
allocating the time for the CPU(i.e. only one thread runs at one time). In order to make
threads back to their previous command positions, every thread has its own PC
3. If the current method is the Java method, the value of the PC register is the
address of the execution in the class file. If the current method is native, the value is
This is the only area that is not required for any type of OutOfMemoryError case.
run-time data areas that are used during execution of a
Some of these data areas are created on JVM
start-up and are destroyed only when the JVM exits.
Other data areas are per thread. Per-thread data areas
are created when a thread is created and destroyed
time constant pool, field and method data, and
the code for methods and constructors
2. It is created by JVM start-up.
it is removed from the heap. It stores in native

all class instances and arrays.( I think it

It is created by JVM start-up.
If a computation requires more heap than can be
available by the automatic storage management
system, the JVM throws an OutOfMemoryError.
1.An implementation of JVM may use conventional
(methods written in a non-Java language.) Also, native
method stacks may be used by the implementation of
an interpreter for JVM's instruction set in a language
2. If supplied, they are typically allocated per thread
If the computation in a thread requires a larger native
method stack than is permitted, the JVM throws a
If native method stacks can be dynamically expanded
and native method stack expansion is attempted but
insufficient memory can be made available, or if
insufficient memory can be made available to create
initial native method stack for a new thread, the JVM
1. It is created by the time when a thread is created.
2. It holds local variables and partial results and plays a part in
If the computation in a thread requires a larger JVM stack than is
permitted, the JVM throws a StackOverflowError.
If JVM stacks can be dynamically expanded, and the expansion is
attempted but insufficient memory can be made available to effect
the expansion, or if insufficient memory can be made available to
create initial JVM stack for a new thread, OutOfMemoryError.
